name: Anna
comment info:
My eyes were first drawn to the large shaded areas that can be found especially on the Chinese, Filipino, Korean, and Japanese population maps. However, this lead me to question why the Filipino map appeared to be shaded in more than the Chinese map when the Chinese population was greater by over 1 million. Thus, I suspected that the large shaded portions likely resulted from the counties in those states being less populated and thus having county lines that are drawn larger. I also noticed that a lot of the shaded areas for the larges Asian populations are in the areas where there are major cities on the east and west coasts.

I wonder what background context and events result in certain populations clustering around areas of interest such as Filipinos  in the mountain region and Alaska, the Japanese in Hawaii, and also how all of the smaller Asian populations came to gather in the few areas they show up on the map. I am curious about the shaded region at the very bottom of where California borders Nevada where it seems many Asian populations, including two of the smaller ones are gathered: Chinese, Korean, Thai, and Laotian.

This relates to me as an Asian-American, particularly one belonging to the largest group the Chinese, because it shows me just how immensely diverse the Asian racial group is. It's been fascinating observing where these different populations tend to gather and seeing where I fall.

Where do Asian Populations tend to Concentrate and Cluster in the US?

name: Moderator Ben Kirk
comment info:
Thanks to all students who responded. Here are some of the catchy headlines that we received: "How Major Asian Groups Are Dispersed in the Country" by Colleen of Academy of Saint Elizabeth in Morristown, New Jersey; "Asians in America: Scattered or Clustered Across the States" by S of Pennsylvania and “The Asian Population in America is Coasting” by Fiona and “Asians on the Map” by Erin, both of USA.

name: Garrett Allen
comment info:
First, I notice something that does not surprise me much: that there is a concentration of Asian populations on the West Coast -- specifically in the Los Angeles, Bay Area, and Seattle areas -- and to a lesser extent in New England in the east. I also notice, encouragingly, that these Asian populations in the United States are /everywhere/, all over the place, from Alaska to Utah to Texas to Maryland. I notice that the smaller groups are not often located in the Deep South, with some exceptions like Vietnamese famously South, Laotians in Louisiana and Thai folks in Mississippi. Numerically, I notice that the population numbers are /huge/, with millions and millions of Asian folks living across the Union.

I wonder about why there are concentrations of Asian populations in parts of the Southwest, like Southwest Texas, or Phoenix, or Southeastern Utah, of all places. I wonder why Hmong folks in California are mainly in the center, away from the famous coast. I wonder why there aren't big populations of more Asian groups in Hawaii. Maybe Hawaii is too expensive or does not carry enough economic promise? 

As a St. Louisan, I do not think our city is famous for its Asian populations. But as a Midwesterner, I am excited to see folks -- especially Filipinos -- across the Midwest. It also seems like Minnesota and Wisconsin are doing great to attract big populations. Overall, I get an impression of unity: "Asia is Our Ally: Asian Populations Extend Across the Entirety of the Union."

name: Ariel Wang
comment info:
Asian explosion
 
As can be seen from the graph, the Asian population in the US is as high as 20 million, while the Chinese population in mainland China is as high as 4.1 million. In second place is India, with an estimated population of 4 million. While most Chinese still live in the West, Asian communities are increasingly established in the southern suburbs and rural Midwest. I wonder whether some ethnic minorities were among the first immigrants who were largely determined by chance. Immigrant families or individuals initially choose a certain place by accident, and then their relatives and friends often choose to go to the same place, taking full advantage of their ethnic social network, thereby reducing the risk cost of immigration. Because of this, the population distribution of ethnic minorities has a relatively fixed geographical distribution. It is related to me and my community a lot. First, I'm glad to see that Asians are more and more widely distributed in the United States today, because international students like me will have more and more choices in the future. Since the outbreak of COVID-19 last year, the situation of Asians in the United States has drawn attention as social and demographic dispersion has intensified in Europe and the United States. Last but not least, the increase in Asians is a feature of cultural integration. As the population explosion with wide area, and community with a shared future for mankind, cultures can be blended and innovated.
